reviewText:
An action/adventure game with fairly dull gameplay and a story that ends weak.

Pros:
- Very nice graphics, pretty environments, vivid post-apocalyptic setting
- Story keeps you interested, at least in the beginning
- Strange, but good flavor, evokes a certain amount of feeling which kept me going
- Somewhat interesting characters

Cons:
- Combat is dull and uninspired, it tried to be Batman, but without any skill needed for combos.  You basically mash buttons until your enemy dies.
- The story made me want to keep playing, but towards the ending it becomes a bit predictable.
- Upgrades don't have much variety, if you don't pick the combat and health ones, you're doing it wrong
- Very little character growth throughout the story, there's a supposed love developing between the characters but there's never any payoff


In depth:
I actually started out liking this game, but as I played it began to wear on me.

I am not a fan of story driven games that makes you explore to find power-ups, it not only slows things down, but it also kills any sense of immersion that was developing.  Exciting things were happening in game, and I was constantly behind them because I was still looking for power-ups.  A player should be encouraged to role-play while they game, not to climb every ♥♥♥♥ing cliff to find a glowy sphere.  If you need to put that ♥♥♥♥ in the game, have a section of the game where the action stops, and the player is encouraged to explore an area for an in-game reason.  Most of the time I can forgive this type of thing, however, this game had a ridiculous amount of spheres that could be easily seen and climbed to as you progressed.  As the game went on, I found myself annoyed because I was climbing some wall to get a sphere while my companion was yelling for help or taking cover even though she was in no real danger.

Another thing that bothered me was the character arcs.  The relationship between the protagonist and his captor did not really go anywhere (at least not on screen).  You get the sense that they cared for each other, but nothing ever really came of it.

I will say, however, there were some very good looking scenery pieces that made me stop and admire.  The setting, landscapes, and feel of the post-apocalyptic wasteland is probably the best feature of this game.

Overall, there are better action/adventure games than this one.  I would stay clear of this one unless it's on-sale for really cheap.  But even then, I didn't finish the game with a satisfied feeling.  I could have overlooked the sub-par gameplay if the story elements had played out better.  I understand why the game never got any sequels.

reviewText:
The beginning of this game is captivating and it definitely has the beginnings of a great story, but as a PC port I find the menu and control system intolerable.  I have spent more time editing the .ini files than playing the game (which isn't much time, really) and am now giving up trying to make it functional.  At one point I was asked to press and hold a button which does not work (middle mouse button); went to change the binding in the options menu so that I could comply and discovered that bindings cannot be changed during gameplay, only from the main menu.  This prompted the loss of about fifteen minutes of gameplay which is unfortunate, but fine if it means I can have a good gameplay experience.  It happens.  While out of the game, I also took the opportunity to try to fix some of the more aggravating gameplay issues such as the inability to change the mouse sensitivity in-game (which is set exceptionally low), the abhorrent camera angles and camera controls and the observation that changing the graphics settings in-game has no effect on the graphics.   After an hour of messing around in the initialization files and succeeding only in changing the graphics settings and neither the camera controls or mouse sensitivity, I gave up.

To think that a modern game requires the editing of initialization files to effect changes that appear in the menu system but do not function is really mind-blowing.

This game looks fantastic, and the story looks great, but I have little tolerance for fighting the controls more than I'm fighting the enemies around me.

reviewText: Don't get me wrong. The storyline is exciting, the graphics are beautiful, the voice acting (particularly that by Andy Serkis, but yes, in general) is fantastic. It's also exciting to know that I'm playing as a character who was mocapped by Andy Serkis. However.\n\nThis is the one of the worst, and laziest, PC ports imaginable. There are game-breaking bugs throughout the game, the kind that require a walkthrough to find a workaround; and I'm not even to the end of it yet. If you can get it for console instead of PC, I strongly recommend that. However, I would not spend more than five dollars on the PC port. Video handling is atrocious, graphics are much too tightly bound to the same system as controls, and throughout the game, you will face no greater enemy than the freakin' camera angle. It felt worse than DIstrict 9. There were cases where Monkey (that's your hero) would attack at angles that had nothing to do with anything, exposing you to getting torn to shreds by a bunch of otherwise-trivial robots. There were cases in which the camera angle rotated literally 180 degrees, and it took me thirty seconds to figure out how to cross an otherwise insignificant bridge because he kept turning around halfway. There are controller instructions that make zero sense for a mouse and keyboard (I'm still trying to figure out where X" and "B" are.) Perhaps most obnoxiously
date: whoever did game-camera direction seemed to think they were making a major motion picture instead of a game
recommended: because a lot of the angles serve literally no purpose other than trying to make you look cool. (While dying
hoursPlayed: evidently.)\n\nAnd let's not forget the on-again-off-again problems with the scripted AI. There are many occasions in which a plot-essential event won't occur because a character has stopped in the middle of the floor
voteText: instead of completing their scripted action. The game's save mechanism is pretty much identical to Price of Persia's
helpfulPercent: except I'm not aware of any cue that appears when I get to a checkpoint. (If you've played "Ghostbusters" by Terminal Reality

to my knowledge.

It takes a lot to make me recommend a console over PC

reviewText:
Enslaved : Odyssey to the West has an amazing storyline with a beautifull background-

Our heros actions take part on a pos-apocalyptic world, just like Fallout but, showing us the opposite of a wasteland. A beautifull world taken over by nature.

Sadly the pc port to this game was awfully done, and is one of the reasons I wouldnt recommend this game for the pc. Plus, if you are playing with K&M forget about it.. Seems like they didnt even bother showing the controls, and just showcase the combos for the PC version, with Xbox360 buttons.
Plus you'll waste more hours trying to jump around a corner than you will playing the game. I couldnt even get past chapter 4 till i got tired of trying to get around that corner (having already encountered 2 game breaking gliches and another corner i caught before spending 10 min to pass it.)

Story 8.5/10
Graphics 8/10
Gameplay 4/10
Port 1/10

reviewText:
I gave this game a really good swing and found it a lackluster flyball in comparison to the all too positive reviews posted for it.  Nitpickingly - it's a console port to PC and there is noticable clunkiness due to that which I'll get into later (outside of displaying prompts as B or Y when the pc hotkeys would be E or F respectly).

The storyline is extremely linear and little can be said about the basis which is heavily inspired by another work (The Monkey King and Journey to the east), the character voice acting and animations (especially facial cues) were pretty spot on but overall each one left me very little to grow attached to.  I could see the obvious portryal of tropes but I found the main character too much of a masked Marty Stu which went against the backdrop of the badass" character.  The Extras side option from the main menu called Pigsy's perfect 10 actually found more personality in the main character albeit a bit disgusting but at least humorous one than from the main protagonist.

The female protaganist Trip went to almost Navi levels of annoying at times with her nagging but overall not too bad of a partner to have through the long escort mission that is this game due to having some abilities.... but that's where gameplay comes in.

There were so many missed opportunities to do something actually interesting with this partnership dynamic that is the center of this story that the few interactions you do get to do (sticking a syringe in my neck to heal me or using holographic decoy) were far outshadowed by the problematic issues of having the funsucking job of babysitting.  Some of the clunkiness comes out in sections where you have to "throw" your partner to a platform only to have her scrambling from the ledge due to an inadequate throw - and you having to jump across on a timer in order to haul her up and save her (consequently saving you).  The problem from that example comes when the character refuses to jump in the direction of the platform which is OBVIOUS because you are playing on a keyboard without an analog stick thus having to replay sections just to do the same nonsensical event over again.  This happened throughout the playthrough at least 3x at different sections
date: which is why it stuck with me at all and also showed itself on time wasting "platforming" where you basically push a direction and spam the spacebar.  The last 2(?) levels out of the 14 actually started adding in "timing" for these jumps but for the majority of this game it is a complete waste of time and adds no challenge
recommended: content or fun to the game outside of padding hours played.  One of my biggest peeves "WHY CAN YOU NOT SKIP CUTSCENES OF CINEMATICS IN THIS GAME?" It's not like this was impossible to do technically in the game since you "can" skip the epilogue by clicking by mistake and bringing yo uto the then "unskippable" credit reel.  Nothing is more annoying than continuing your progress in this game the next day to be subject to the same 4 minute cinematic or if you experience a cheap death or bug (which also happened where Trip wouldn't activate a console to progress the gameplay) that you have to watch the entire cinematic over again... WHY?\n\nCombat has some positives - it's reactive there are quite a varied amount of abilities to use but it feels overtly easy at the beginning and progressively annoying at later stages.  The mechs are most annoying when shield types swarm you while you need to complete a specific objective quickly (namely the 12th
hoursPlayed: 13th and 14th stages) especially if they don't conveniently give you a "special" tactical mech in order to exploit (such as an explosive or electrical one).  This only ramps up the difficulty of the game in an unsatisfying way as you sit there repeating the "cheapest" of combos in order to overcome these encounters and stifles creativity in the encounters.  Which is what the game comes down to - the combat becomes very very repetitive as you push through it and rarely alleviated by sections where you use a cool "hover cloud" (nimbus tee hee) but as enemies and even bosses become repeated over and over again the levels all start meshing together into one "blah" experience.\n\nWhile I enjoyed the game at the start - somewhere through the game I felt extremely uninterested by what the game had to offer and found myself wandering away to other games.  I basically forced myself to finish it once I realized the general length of the game was fairly short when I saw the achievement list - and cannot find myself recommending it for the 2014 gamer."

reviewText:
Andy Serkis Gets Buff and Beats Robots with a Stick.

Come for a solid action game, stay for the characters.

I remember playing this game on a console when it first came out and never finishing it, due to some pretty solid, but uninspired gameplay, but fast forward a few years, and I find myself playing this game again.  My issue with the game play remains unchanged, but I've come to appreciate the asthetics and presentation.

Andy Serkis (famous for his role of Gollum from Peter Jackson's LOTR trilogy) doubles as the dramatic lead and voice director, while working with a script by Alex Garland (28 Days Later).  While their writing and acting is excellent, it hides the fact the combat is bland and the platforming just doesn't feel that satisfying.  That having been said, if you're the kind of person who plays games for the story, then this would be a worthwhile choice when it's on sale.

reviewText: Pros: Characters are quite well written (especially Trip and Pigsy), some interractions are really funny. The story is interesting and engaging. Visually beautiful game.\n\nCons: Although presented as action" game
date: I'd say it's much more a 3d platformer than anything else (with some easy puzzles thrown in). The game is linear - the only choices you get are in the "chasing mechs sequences" where you can take 1 out of the 2 paths (no effect on story). Everything else in the game is linear - there is only one way to progress through the level. There are some questionable mechanics - the controls are always camera based (pressing A makes Monkey run left in relation to the camera
recommended: not the actual left of the character). This wouldn't be a problem
hoursPlayed: except the game sometimes "takes over" the camera by locking it somewhere in the corner of a room etc. It's a little annoying
voteText: but not game breaking. The controls in menu or upgrade menu are not very good
helpfulPercent: if you're using a mouse and keyboard.\n\nConclusions: I still recommend the game
votesHelpful: but I would recommend using a controller with this one. You can play with mouse and keyboard - the controller experience is much better. I'd rate it 8/10 (or 7/10 if playing without controller)."

reviewText: I hate this game so much.  This is a perfect example of what developers should not do in a game.  The most powerful enemy in this game is the camera angle.  Good luck trying to get a decent view of the action or a view of the screen that doesn't completely disorient you.   And the sidekick in the game, is a huge pain in the butt.  She doesn't do anything except ask you to help her get across various obstacles and then she holds you up from completing levels.  She is like the anti-Elizabeth in BIoshock Infinite.   She will get in your way and make you hate the entire dev team for not figuring out a better way to make both of these characters act in concert.\n\nPlus, if you do buy this game, I highly suggest turning off motion blur.  The enabled motion blur in this game is strong enough to make someone sick.

reviewText:
Graphics 6/10 - Story 6/10 - Gameplay 5/10 - Controls 6/10 - Overall 6/10

This game fell under my radar until it was ultimately forgotten by pretty much everyone. I generally like to play games once they've sort of fizzled out their popularity, but I'm not sure this one was ever received well enough to be defined as popular.

My first impression, prior to playing, was that this would be a post-apocalyptic, linear exploration game. I wasn't too far off from my expectations, which would be a good thing if the game was any fun. It ends up being a poorly scripted, hack-n-slash, with bad fighting controls and an anticlimactic ending.

The graphics were decent, for the time it was released, but the cartoony and oddly shaped character designs make the realistic set pieces feel odd and out-of-place.

I should mention that Andy Serkis makes a physical appearace throughout the game, and by physical, I mean non-computer-generated"

reviewText:
This game is technically speaking one of the worst console ports I've played:
- Impossible to Alt-Tab
- Impossible to use the mouse pointer in the menu
- Impossible to change settings in-game
- Ugly graphical glitches with the shadows in the cutscenes
- I didn't even manage to change the keyboard settings with the help of ini-file modifications, which wouldn't be so bad if you didn't need to use WASD, the Mouse AND the arrow keys almost simultaneously
- When you unlock new moves, you have to look up on forums what keys you need to press in order to execute them as they only show the Xbox buttons in the game.

The second main weak point of the game is, as many others point out, the gameplay.

Platforming is a joke, you can only die if the wall is crumbling and it takes you longer than 2 seconds to press space and vaguely point in the right direction. Other than that, just mash the space button and WASD and you'll eventually get there. There's some parts where the idea was that you have to time your jumps to avoid fire shooting out of the walls, but at this point in the game you should be maxed on health and health regeneration so you can simply jump straight through the fire as it really is not that taxing on your health.

Aside from combat, the game is just way too easy:
- Puzzles are not really complicated so much as lengthy to solve.
- The camera most of the time points in the direction of where you should be going
- If not, figuring out where to go next boils down to spot the glowing thingy closest to the ground"

What is infuriating about walking from place to place is that they've placed pretty much all of the experience orbs just a little out of the way
date: so you can easily spot them but collecting them is terribly annoying as you have to take a longer route every time.\n\nThe combat is somewhat challenging
recommended: but very repetitive and doesn't offer enough variety
hoursPlayed: neither in the range of moves Monkey has nor in the enemies he faces.\n\nThe story to me wasn't really as compelling as many say it is
voteText: I found it rather thin for my 8 hours of gameplay. It's mainly conveyed in cutscenes. Pigsy was the cringiest character of all time and Trip was little more than a sex object. I like Monkey mainly because I like Andy Serkis."

reviewText:
Ten minutes of this game's awful camera made me more nauseous than Super Hexagon, and that's a game where you stare at a flashing, spinning, pulsing, colorshifting strobelight.

The graphics were nice, I guess, but nothing hooked me, gameplay-wise. It seems like a lot of the game is supposed to be a jumping puzzle, but there's only one direction to go and items you can grab and jump on are highlighted, so it's basically a matter of holding a direction and pressing space. Not exactly thrilling, console port or not.

Combat mechanics aren't bad, but they're also not good.

Supposedly the story's pretty good, but story needs to be complemented by half-decent gameplay.

Mostly, I couldn't push past the terrible camera. I know it's hard to design a camera for a game like this, but at the very least it shouldn't induce motion sickness.

reviewText:
A medicre 5/10. Not worth it if you already have other games waiting in the pipeline.

The game is extrmely linear, on rails and everything is repetitive, from combat to acrobatics.  Controls are acceptable, but not tuned for K+M.

Still playable at 60fps, but has very dated graphics. Textures are in particular very very low rez.

The story/characters are the only redeeming features of the game, although fairly cliche and predictable . Game can be beaten in about 9-10 hours.

reviewText: What Enslaved has going for it is beautiful environments, great character design, professional voice acting (as in actual actors), good music, all the artistic things. Andy Serkis had a big part in the voice acting and motion capture performance, and you can really see it. But when it comes to actual gameplay, it's not that great.\nThe enemies are very repetitive and the controls on the PC are really wonky. You can tell the controls are meant to be used on a console and the PC port wasn't super smooth. There was one move that I leveled up and couldn't use because the instructions for it were for an XBOX controller. .\nGetting around consists a lot of jumping from ledge to ledge, which is cool in the beginning but it gets old. you can only jump off specific ledges, and plenty of times you can't jump off a simple small ledge because you can only jump from certain spots. The exception to this is the cloud" which is like an air surfing thingimajig
recommended: but you only use it in certain spots
hoursPlayed: and also it's hard to use.\nHonestly

reviewText: Kind of a mixed bag in this game. On the plus side: it looks nice, it's atmospheric and has good acting. On the negative side: the story is kind of thin, the controls are really awkward (very, very much to blame there is the fact it's a direct console port, with no regard for PC controls).\n\nWhat breaks everything for me though is constantly having to fight the camera. Sure, having certain angles makes things more cinematic" like but it really isn't conducive to smooth gameplay if you are at the mercy of odd
date: switching camera angles that can hit you often at the most inopportune moments. I've lost progress several times just because of that - having to play through the same part of the story (without being able to skip cutscenes) just because the gamemakers decided to sharply rotate (requiring directional adjustment) or completely swap camera angle in high-action spots ruins the game. It's a common mistake made in these kinds of games

reviewText: Enslaved is a mostly overlooked game by the developer Ninja Theory, the same guys who later went on to make the controversial reimagining of the Devil May Cry franchice DmC".\n\nIt takes its inspiration from a classic Chinese novel
date: but places it in a post apocalyptic American setting. The premise is certainly intriguing
recommended: but the game is in my opinion held back by its weird gameplay decisions and annoying AI characters.\n\nThe gameplay is a mix between Gears of War style cover based shooting and Prince of Persia style platforming sections. It also has some melee combat for good measure. Enslaved pretty much mixes and matches different elements from different inspirations
hoursPlayed: but these elements really lack dept. Combat boils down to tapping a few different attack buttons and rolling away
voteText: while the platforming sections work with a context sensitive "platforming" button. You can complete pretty much 90% of all the platforming by just pressing up on the analog stick and mashing the platforming button. Probably the most refined thing is the cover based shooter mechanic
helpfulPercent: but it is also the one that feels the most out of place for this type of game.\n\nThe game is also totally relient on your AI partner characters
votesHelpful: and the experience is very much on rails. You always have a partner character yelling instructions at you. This really makes the game feel like you are just a dumb monkey following instructions rather than figuring out stuff for yourself
votesTotal: which is ironic
votesFunny: because in the story you actually are ENSLAVED (get it!?!) by another person and have to follow his orders.\n\nA lot of the game areas are decayed versions of actual American landmarks
commentsCount: and that might be memorable if you are American and patriotic or just generally like cool looking video game levels
column16: but I kind of just breezed through all that not giving it much thought. The visuals of the game are very good and especially the character animations during combat look impactful. It looks like a decent PS3/XB360 era game. I had some minor problems with the shadows
column17: but they might have been caused by some graphics card driver incompatibility rather than the game itself.\n\nIn the end I would probably not recommend Enslaved. It's an interesting game
column18: but more so in a bad way. It has some bizzare gameplay elements that really don't work together and the AI character nagging and the blatant linearity of the game is annoying in an interesting fashion. If you really want to see Prince of Persia and Gears of War come together in an interesting game setting you might want to give this a shot
column19: but the probability of anyone wanting that is quite low."

reviewText:
Key word: Frustrating.

I tried so hard to like this game. I really did. However, I've never come across a port which makes a game so frustratingly unplayable.

At first it had everything I'd normally love in a game - Breaktaking visuals, a gripping plot from the beginning and a feeling of freedom and fluidity in the movement and combat which is great (despite linear pathing and encounters). Also some of the best voice acting I've come across from a game in a while. The thing that lets it down is the actual 'game' part of it.

As many people here have mentioned, this is a port from the xbox. After half an hour of playing around with the mouse sensitivity controls, I accepted that it didn't have a setting which made it usable. A slight twitch and you're aiming the other side of the area, but somehow the mechs still run faster than your deaccelerated aim mode, making the turret sections frustratingly difficult. Further than this, the camera controls have a life of their own and you'll be fighting for control the entire time while being ripped apart by the enemies. Combine this with long checkpoint respawns and having to run around to the ends of the map every time to collect the tech orbs for an ultimate grind.

On top of this the port has a number of unpatched bugs, which left me stranded on a pole on the side of the building, unable to jump around a corner no matter what I try or how many times I reloaded (still not sure how I made it past after 30 minutes). The developers didn't even update the control guidelines for the PC, so every time I learned I new move, I had to minimise the game to google the equivilent PC controls.

Conclusion:
Seems like it could be a great game on the xbox. However, worst port of any game I've ever come across onto PC, making the game unplayable, frustrating and hindered by gamebreaking bugs. DO NOT buy for PC.

reviewText:
Can't comment on the story as I could not progress pass mid-Chapter 2.

This is a crappy console port (one of the worst that I have ever seen) that makes the assumption that one plays PC games exclusively with a Console controller, and not Keyboard + Mouse, and certainly not an alternative Input device such as a Trackball or a Gamepad. It does not have any options for Key or Mouse bindings, and as such if your Input device doesn't have, say a Middle-Mouse button for instance, you simply cannot play.

On top of that, the game assumes that you have an Analog stick to constantly reorient the camera. There are no camera controls for K+M or other Input devices. As such, the camera gets stuck at a weird angle making platform jumping and combat difficult at best, and at worst makes you nauesous as it constantly spins around.

I shouldn't have expected anything more than a sub-par Console port from Namco Bandai (they are as bad as Capcom). The Japanese are so rigid (and outdated) in their thinking that PC gaming nothing more than an afterthought, and simply cannot fathom why anyone would play a game with something other than a Console controller even when their business depends upon it.

If you game with a Console controller then Y.M.M.V.

reviewText:
Beautiful game! The story is captivating and takes you in right from the start. Lousy port though. That pretty much sums up this review. Continue reading for more specifics.

Let's start with the good. Definitely get this game on sale, the story is definitely worth 5 bucks and once you get the hang on the controls and the annoying camera, you'll have a great time with it :)
I just ended my first session after 1,5 hours, because it's 2AM and I need to get some sleep. I planned to play this for half an hour, just to check it out, but the story and characters grabbed me and didn't let go. Even now, I actually want to go back and continue to find out what's going on...

The gameplay, however, is rather lazy. But I'm pretty sure you want this game for the story, not for the brawler combat, not for the Baby-Prince-of-Persia"-esque platforming (you can't miss a jump
date: you can't fall - I'm still wondering if you can even die in this game)
recommended:

reviewText:
One of the most moving RPG games I've played in a long time. It just sad that it didn't find it's way to the spotlight, and therefor a sequel seems an impossibility. I'm so glad it made it's way to PC.

With brilliant motion capture from actors like Andy Serkis (Gollum - Lord of the Rings/The Hobbit Trilogies), the emotions from the characters are very believable, and make your actions that much more meaningful. Great visuals and a fantastic soundtrack add to the story even moreso. The gameplay is great fun, with acrobatic elements and teamwork between Monkey and Trip, meaning a good blend between action and environmental puzzles, which can also come into play during combat, which is a great stress reliever with epic finishing moves and great sound engineering to enhance those smashy" sounds.

The only place that the game fell short for me was the staff's "aim and fire" feature
date: although this is only required in a few points of the game
recommended: so you won't have to rely on it. That
hoursPlayed: and sometimes the game would have trouble realising which object to whilst making use of acrobatics; although almost every game with this kind of "play" has this issue
voteText: so it's quick to learn how to minimalise it with certain camera angling and/or stick pushing.\n\nA unique and moving game I strongly recommend to those who love a good story
helpfulPercent: but still like to smash some robots in the face."

reviewText: Unfortunately, I cannot recommend buying this game on PC, and it's not because it's a bad game. I wouldn't even know if it was, because I couldn't play it at all. Every time I tried to, the game froze. Or a humonguous amount of lag, not just a few seconds, or delay between sound and video. It took me about 20 minutes from the Press Start to begin screen until all the intro cinematic was done and the game started. And then, every time I tried moving, jumping, I got these huge lag spikes/frozen screen. I could not play the game. And I am bummed out because of it. I looked at the game's system requirements, , and while I don't have state of the line PC, it passed the req. Still, no game for me, and therefore I cannot recommend this game on PC. Maybe if you have the latest specs.

reviewText: I love this game.  This is one of my favorite games.......on the PS3 that is!  The story is great.  The characters are great.  This game was really developed for the PS3, not the PC.  You can tell they put very little effort into the PC version.  For the PC, the camera is terrible, the controls are terrible, the screen will jump all over the place, etc.  I really do not recommend the PC version of this game.  I do, however, highly recommend the PS3 version of this game.  Also, in the early part of Chapter 2, you will get stuck. Trip will lower a bridge but the other side is stuck.  Monkey climbs around to the other side, however, there is one part where he needs to jump from a pipe to a wall and it just doesn't happen.  I've tried everything, from exiting and restarting, to replaying the chapter many times, to exploring first before climbing, and I always get stuck at the same place and just can't go any further.  So, no, I would definitely not recommend the PC version of this game but if you have a PS3 then absolutely get it!

reviewText:
How something so colourful can be so dull is anyones guess but sure enough thats precisely what you get with enslaved.

I had hoped for more but at the very least even the story failed to impress and thus make this a jumbled piece of nonsense that quite frankly cant be considered a game.

Its an old story revamped to play out in the future where once again we see the cant be controlled monkey be corralled by a mystical headband which in the future is nothing more than certain death while the monk from the story of old is replaced with a woman called Trip. The pair agree a deal to work together to reunite Trip with her people which while forming part of most of the beginning levels is just a rue for yet another AI romance forged through hardship and toil.

As for the game aspect their is none, its all go their do this, do that and repeat, repeat, repeat. You get to collect orbs along the way for upgrade purposes but sadly they feel nothing more than a downgrading of skill level rather than a souping up of arsenal which isnt that diverse to begin with.

All in all i was unimpressed and find it hard to recommend this game on any point, even when going cheap in a steam sale so its a thumbs down for me this time

reviewText:
ENSLAVED™: Odyssey to the West™ Premium Edition on the PC is an infuriating experience (played on normal difficulty)

The game is only worth playing for the story, which is interesting, well told and the character animation is very well done.

Now the controls is where this game hits the floor, the camera goes bonkers during combat and the controls are not very responsiv. The aiming... , thank god the aiming reticule goes red when I am on target, because otherwise I would be lining every shot up for 20 minutes.

The most memorable part of the game was the first chase scene, because I died a lot - A LOT! and I did not even know you could skip the long cutscene that immideatly follows the previous checkpoint. Apparently they never felt the need to tell us you can skip cutscenes. BACKSPACE is the key that allows you to SKIP CUTSCENES folks. That combined with some bad decisions in the upgrade tree from my part (went everything into armor thinking it would keep me alive longer) made combat a nightmare made me curse out loud I closed the game because it made me angry and filled me with regret for buying this game, so I can't really reccomend this to other people.

Don't buy it - unless you like console ports and have massochistic tendencies - if you do buy it - play on the easiest difficult and upgrade your stun capabilities.

I repeated configuring, watching the same movie, it kept scrambling my key bindings. I found that some people have the same problems. I think it originally was designed for XBox or PS3 or both, not PC, they didn't bother much to fix for PC version. We need PC police to inspect games before they can sell.

reviewText:
Follow a gripping, surprise-filled journey as two dissimilar characters form an uneasy partnership in order to survive through a perilous, post-apocalyptic America.

150 years in the future, war and destruction have left the world in ruins with few humans remaining and nature having reclaimed the world. Mysterious slave ships harvest the dwindling population and take them out west, never to return.

Trip, a technologically savvy young woman has been imprisoned by a slave ship but manages to escape using her mental prowess. Monkey, a strong, brutish loner and fellow prisoner also gets free by virtue of his raw power and brawn. Trip quickly realizes that Monkey is her ticket to freedom and is her only hope to survive her perilous journey back home. She hacks a slave headband and fits it on Monkey, linking them together. If she dies, he dies and her journey has now become his. ENSLAVED centers on the complex relationship between the two main characters. Players take on the role of Monkey, utilizing a mix of combat, strategy and environmental traversal to ensure he and Trip survive the threats and obstacles that stand in the way of their freedom.

The controls just suck donkey gonads. the camera is jerky and blurry. I thought maybe I can decrease mouse sensitivity, it did absolutly nothing. The crashing and freezing almost couldnt make it over a spot because it was time sensitive and the controls werent responding fast enough. Your character can jump huge distances cant step over a  small boulder. It sucks because I really wanted see the story develop but the game mechanics suck so hard that I can play it for maybe 5 minutes before I log off in digust.

reviewText:
I am torn about this game - it is based on a Chinese epic, and many many scenes definitelity give us the feel of this being an epic odyssey...  Voice acting is superb (Andy Serkis!) and gameplay is fun (although the normal setting is pretty easy IMHO)

The down side: Controls and Camera are HORRID, many glitches will have you thwor your controller in frustration. screen freezing, voice off-set by a second or two in a few scenes looking at walls when you are getting hit by three bots....
But, personally the clunky controls for a platform game of this magnitude is a game breaker. I went all the way to chapter 11 (out of 15) and could not take it anymore.

Buy it for fun - ON SALE - play it on HARD mode for an actual challenge, but expect some frustrating moments along the way.

reviewText: TL;DR: This game is really cool and you smash giant robots and stuff.\nI bought this game without high expectations to be honest, it was an impulse buy because I was tired of playing CS:GO on the same maps over and over again. It was a really refreshing and fun experience. The gameplay isn't anything really new or exciting, but the story and scenery make up for it. I have always liked post-apocalyptic themes, and this game really gets it right. Some people have complained about it's last-generation graphics, but for me it didn't really have a factor in how cool the setting is. I didn't actually realize that the graphics were outdated until someone pointed it out in the community hub. I was interested through the entire game, and there are several really exciting boss battles. I felt like a total badass destroying gigantic war mechs with just a staff. Nobody I know has played, or even heard of this game, which is kind of sad considering the high quality of it. It took my 7 hours to complete the game. I played with controller, I didn't try keyboard/mouse controls. Thumbs up.

reviewText:
I was pleasantly surprised to see Namco taking a chance on a script and game like Enslaved Odyssey to the West. The dialogue and interactions between Monkey and Trip as their friendship/enslavedment progresses is entertaining and well written with not a lot of cheesy cringeworthy ENGRISH dialogue or moments.

There's a decent amount of variety in combat, enemies, level design and puzzles to keep you entertained for a while throughout the action packed story. Voice acting is top notch as are Monkey's movement and animations, however most of this kinda goes downhill and stale towards the last 2 hours of the game and the lackluster ending.

The game will sometimes confuse you with its fixed camera angles during certain moments while you climb in order to force a certain perspective or view of the scenery which is quite nice, however this can be a little jarring for the player when they're trying to execute certain jumps in a certain direction. Luckily the climbing and movement for the most part is relatively easy and smooth, with little option to drop to your death.

Firing and combat mechanics do get a little repetitive after a while throughout the game, but every once in a while a puzzle or action sequence is introduced to keep things interesting.

As I said, the final 2 hours of the game and the ending are somewhat lackluster, predictable and practically open ended considering the ride you just went through.

But all things considered, 7.5/10.

reviewText:
Based on what I had heard, I went into this game expecting to play an action-adventure movie. I was not disappointed.

The combat, though enjoyable, can get repetitive; the platforming is on autopilot (you literally cannot jump to your death); and the levels are very linear, with some small side paths to find extra collectibles. The focus is on the story, and it’s a good one. Voice acting is top-notch throughout, and in cutscenes you can clearly see the emotion in the characters’ faces.

When I wrote about Tomb Raider, I complained about how much of it felt like I was just watching a movie, but that was in part because my expectations were totally off. With Enslaved, I had a better idea of what to expect, and its story and overall execution were far superior. I really don’t want to talk details about the story, so I’ll just say it’s about two strangers brought together in a post-apocalyptic setting, trying to get home.

If you like story-driven and emotive games, and you don’t mind brawler combat against robots, you should play Enslaved. If you can’t stand pressing buttons to smash robots to pieces, you should at least watch a playthrough.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A random 3rd person action game I picked up because of praises by single reviewers (even though the average ratings were, well, average). It's an entertaining melee/climbing sort of thing with solid enough combat mechanics and a fluid climbing system where you mostly just chill and watch the acrobatics (generally you can't fall). It has a decent story as random action games go, and the dialogue/acting is rather good (e.g. Andy Serkis plays the protagonist). The setting is postapocalyptic, but this time it's not a barren wasteland - you find New York overtaken by lush plant life, for instance. Some of the enviroments are beautiful despite its age (it's a PS3/X360 game from 2010).

The game plays better with a console controller, except for the shooting parts (you get a ranged attack with very limited ammo), which become a real pain in the ♥♥♥. There's also a couple of annoying chase sections. Generally it's an easy game.

So nothing revolutionary, no replay value (fully linear), but it's a good somewhat cinematic title with respectable writing and acting, good for a playthrough. I recommend it if you like the genre in general.

The Premium Edition" on Steam comes with 3 DLC skins that give significant passive buffs (but can only be used after finishing the game once
date: unless you edit some .ini files yourself) and a shorter story mode with a more comical tone where you control a side character from the main game."

reviewText:
This game is a pretty interesting take on the old Chinese tale: Journey to the West. It takes quite a few liberties with the story but the adaptations and changes aren't bad in my opinion.

Pros:
-Great voice acting
-Good Story Telling
-Incredibly colorful and pretty environments

Cons
-Combat is boring as heck
-Story really drags on after a while
-Platforming is really basic

This game's strength lies in its story telling ability....not its gameplay. It's competent in a lot of its core gameplays but I wouldn't describe the actual playing of the game as very fun. What IS entertaining is watching the characters interact and seeing the story progress. It eventually became a matter of springting through most of the level in order to see the next cutscene.

Overall: 6/10 Not a waste of money, but definitely better to wait till it's on sale.

reviewText:
This game is AWESOME! A great adaptation based on the book 'Journey to the West'. Great Characters and development. It was a shame that this game really didn't get the notice or the props it deserved. It is one of the most wonderful stories told in computer games.

The tale of Trip and Monkey takes place in a post-apocalyptic world where they must escape to Trip’s home. Bound together they must learn to survive each other and with each other as they cannot survive alone. Traversing the environment is a mix of puzzle and platforming that requires the pair to work together or die.

Right NOW it's $5. $5 fracking dollars! Do yourself a favor and get it. Beautiful, thoughtful and full of personality and fun, this game is most definitely in my top 10 Favorite games of all time.

reviewText:
Enslaved – Odyssey to the West

Enslaved is one of the most underrated games ever. I really have no idea why this game  performed poorly sales wise. The only thing I can think of is that it was inadequately promoted – Namco Bandai pretty much acknowledge that too.

Anyway don't let the fact that you heard little about it put you off - I can tell you it really is a great game - one of the best games I have ever played IMHO.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=278516371

The game was loosely based on a Chinese Novel but differs from the the original story which set a fantasy version of ancient China, to a post-apocalyptic world some 150 years in the future where human existence is sparse and hard. Only scattered residues of humanity remain but left over war-mechs roam the land, still active from the previous global conflict. The plot revolves around Trip (Tripitaka) a captured slave (and tech wizard) who forces the help and protection of a warrior type 'Monkey', who himself is enslaved. They both escape a sabotaged slaver air-ship and 'Monkey' the protagonist you play as, quickly finds himself at the mercy and control of Trip. Incidentally 'Monkey' is excellently voiced and performed by Andy Serkis (of Gollum fame) who was also Performance Director on the project. In fact all characters in this game are outstandingly portrayed and consequently very believable, this adds to the immersion of the game and story.

Anyhow, you discover Trip is wanting to return to her remote community and requires nay needs Monkey's help to get her there. There's an important twist here, as Monkey, you have little choice in the matter - you can discover the detail of why for yourself – and you are tied to her in an interesting way. You find that you often have to piggy back her to difficult to reach places and physically throw her to ledges and across gaps. Its sounds strange but its actually a neat mechanic. My small beef was there ought to have been even more requirement to control and this would have enhanced the experience and tightened the relationship you have with them as characters. I would also have preferred that you could have had an extended command structure both ways but like I said it is a minor niggle.

The fight mechanism is quite extensive and there were many ways I found to complete tasks and defeat enemies and the overall feel was rewarding and that goes for the Boss Fights too. While the story and scope to explore is limited it never really felt that way as in certain areas you had quite a bit of freedom to do things in your own style. Anyway visually, its great to look at too and all movement and animations are solid and fluid. For me, after only a short while you easily get to grow to like these characters and there's a real affinity you get for each of the characters plight.

I highly recommend this game and if you happen to see it in Steam Sales, I suggest you get it. I'm sure you wont be disappointed!

reviewText:
Combat and platforming feel a lot like the Prince of Persia series (especially PoP 2008), which I find very fun to play with. Wielding a staff to beat the [excrement] out of robots, to crush them to pieces is so satifying even though there aren't any real combos at all.

The best thing about this game, however, is its story and the main characters. Watching the duo helping eachother, fighting their way through beautiful sceneries and stunning landscapes as their relationship changes made me smile. Great chemistry.
Oh yea and the graphics is beautiful, even though it's a 3 year old game (and a console port).

Perhaps my only gripe is the ending. Not going to spoil anything so I'll just say that I hate cliffhangers. That said, ENSLAVED is still a great game and it will always have a place in my heart. I haven't enjoyed a game this much for a while.

To be fair, it's a solid 7 but I give it a 9/10 for all the joy it gave me.

I recommend this hidden gem.

reviewText: First I felt guilt for tacking another $5 on to my total in the last minutes of the Summer sale.  Then I started the game and that was replaced with guilt for having waited this long to play it.  I don't know the sale numbers on console, but the relatively little amount of chatter has me thinking this title was painfully overlooked.  Controls could stand to be a liiiittle bit tighter and combat isn't all that complex, but the voice acting, character animations, interactions, and set pieces so far are top notch.  It's a console port, so there was some .ini editing (resolution, shadow, AA, Aniso and such either not available in menus or don't stick when set) and PC trickery to be done (D3DOverrider for Vsync), but once that's done, it's a beautiful, brilliantly crafted game.  Think God of War meets Uncharted in a sci-fi setting.

reviewText:
I am on chapter 9 with 5 hours played, I like this game.

One problem i have with this game are due to the controls, which are not surfaced for some moves, for instance i had to google how
to use the stun hit, because it doesn't say in game. And sometimes the controls not responsive. Sometimes i would be in a fight and try to run and my analogue
stick ( i use a xbox controller ) would not respond for a second.

My other problem, is more with the climbing, which this game relies on heavily, they do highlight the polls, and some climbable objects,
but not all of them. They also do not highlight them too well, its a shiny effect type of thing from the original uncharted. I wish they would
have used a eagal vision type of thing.

My third, very minor, nit pick problems are the camera angles change your controls sometimes, this also happens in DmC: Devil May Cry, which i
see as a more analogue comparison, seeing as Ninja theory made both. The pre-rendered cutsenes look like they were made with 3d software from 1999, and
rendered to a gif. Also sometimes the animations arnt very smooth, this isn't usually a problem until the game makes you zoom into your 'AI partner' ( not really
an AI partner, more of a highly scripted partner ) and you see the animations up close.

What i like about it...

This game has deep characters, which i think Ninja Theory actually dose very well. Their seems to be a character arch, but seeing as im
only on chapter 9, i cant tell you how it ends.

The world they created is interesting, and i want to find out where it ends. As much as they chalk up to 'Video Games' AKA a magic hoverboard that only works sometimes,
it all works within the story, and they are very good at propositioning my questions, such as 'why dose that only work here'.

The Story is good, no spoilers.

Overall, I usually don't finish games, I actually might finish this one.

EDIT:
After finishing this game at 8 hours, i want to say, i still agree, with my earler review, the boss fights can be frustrating when they make you jump around, and the story is OMG worth it.

reviewText:
Brilliant game, one of the few that can actually make an impact and teach you a thing or two about yourself. I am ashamed it took me so long to discover this amazing title. Spectacular cinematics, most beautiful environment ever encountered in a game, breathtaking (literally!) acrobatics, instantly likeable and believable characters, stunning acting and voiceovers - everything about this game is amazing, stunning and awesometastic :D I was impressed so much that I actually bought a hardcopy collector's edition *after* I played the steam version, it's THAT good.

The only minor drawback is the issue with some cameras fighting you for the best viewing angle, but it is not happening often, and never in vital points. Autosave does a great job in letting you restart the failed bit right where you dropped it, cut scenes are letting the story flow very naturally, autoplatforming does its job, you are here to aid Monkey in his awesome jumping and climbing, not in figuring out where to place your hands next, most of the times. How many times have you encountered a game in which the characters are out of breath and panting when speak right after fighting off a hoard of mechs or jumping their way over an abyss almost falling down while doing so?

10/10 in my book, would totally play a sequel/prequel/spinoff, just put Monkey in it and let me watch him swing from one ledge to another for another 15 hours or so, the longer the better. And this time I will not hesitate to purchase full price pre-release version at that!

reviewText:
A solid game...that's also very lazy.

The characters are very likable and the story is decent. In fact, it's what kept me playing even when the rest started to become a little tedious. The post-apocalyptic setting is well done with some nice locales mixed in.

Unfortunately, those were the only outstanding aspects to me. The rest was just mediocre. The combat, while moderately challenging on hard, is very barebones. It has a very basic moveset that doesn't get expanded upon very much. That means that you're stuck with the same 3 attacks (light, heavy, aoe) for the most part. It could've used a more fleshed out skill progression system where you actually unlock new stuff to do. What makes the combat worse is the lack of enemy variety. There are 4 enemy types that get thrown at you and that's pretty much it. The 2 bosses that get recycled over and over again throughout the game don't help much either. It's not like there wasn't enough room to be creative, since the enemy are supposed to be mechs of all kinds and sizes.

The platforming"
recommended: didn't contribute much to the gameplay. It's basically climbing and parkour stuff along a very streamlined path with 0 danger of failure. I didn't mind this very much
hoursPlayed: but it could definitely have been more.\n\nI still recommend this since I enjoyed the overall experience
voteText: but only at a discount (picked it up for 5€)."

reviewText: A severely underrated game. Pros involved an interesting plot, fascinating translation of setting (compared to the original material), nuanced characters and very, VERY good performance acting (voice and motion included). The combat is repetitive, but I found it to be acceptable. My one complaint about the game would be that the world and action is far too often interrupted by small unskippable cutscenes to further the puzzle/platforming in the areas. Normal, pre-rendered or plot-based cutscenes were fine, but continually halting my gameplay just to show me where an obvious switch was or the path I needed to take to progress was got to be a bit disappointing when I was trying to enjoy the game and immerse myself.\n\nThat small negative aside, the game truly is a hidden gem. It's soulful, has a lot of heart, and will grab you within the first 10min of gameplay (if it doesn't, then maybe it isn't the game for you). Purchased this with zero expectations since I had never heard of it and was absolutely blown away by the quality of writing, production, and entertainment. While there has been multiple confirmations that there is likely to be no sequel, I strongly hope that the cult following the game has garnered might help revive the effort. Your purchase of this product will help show (hopefully) that this critically acclaimed (but commercially unsuccessful) game has not gone unnoticed, and definitely not unloved.

reviewText: Now, this game is a special one. It is easily overlooked becasue of it's gameplay. It's a simple game with not very many mechanics, but this game takes simplicity and turns it into an adventure. A beautiful world with gorgeous scenery, and characters that seem almost real, they interact with each other, and develop smoothly. And that is what makes this game what it is. Moving on to the actual gameplay, the main caracter Monkey has serious acrobatic skills, which can lead to very intruiging scenes that can have your heart pounding, and combat that seems similar to Batman with some really flashy finishers for simple enemies. So to wrap it up, this game is surely worth checking out. And I highly recommend you do so.

reviewText: A good game. The story is pretty interesting and the characters are memorable. The world is visually attractive. The gameplay reminds me of a cross between Uncharted, meets God of War, meets the Last of Us, with a fairly timing oriented hack and slash melee combat. The climbing mechanics look almost identical to an Uncharted game, which is a good thing in my opinion. You have an upgrade system which adds a little more replayability to the game. The premium edition comes with a whole seperate story-line with completely different game mechanics to really change things up as well as some unlockable buffs to the main story.\n\nMy biggest issue with the game, would be that the controls don't seem very optimized for mouse and keyboard. They're perfectly functional as I played the entire game using only the mouse and keyboard, however the mouse acceleration is a little funky and the some of the game's context menus on give button combinations in terms of an Xbox controller rather than mouse and keyboard. If you're ok with using a controller, then you'll have no complaints however. The camera angles were the second biggest issue, with some scene forcing you into somewhat awkward camera angles which could make doing certai nthings difficult. 95% of the game however, most of the camera angles were fine in my opinion.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Enslaved: Odyssey to the West is a nice game, and it is worth getting if you can get it, and its DLC, on sale.

Enslaved is a above average game, it isn't going to change your views on action adventure, or make you obsess with the source material (it is a reimaging of Journey to the West). But it is a fun experience that is easy to get into.  The main thing holding this title back is that for everything that it does right, it also kind of does it wrong.

Starting off the story for the game is a mix bag. On the positive side you have fun characters that play off each other fairly well. They have playful banter and the audio for them is good. On the negative the overall story is thin and never really explored. At best you'll have a vague idea of what is going on, why you are doing something, or what the point is. Which is a shame, since it seems like the story might have been interesting if they had bother to explain it.

Next the combat for the game is enjoyable, but very simple. You have two attack buttons and two ammo types for your staff gun thingy. And after the 3rd or 4th level, you pretty much know everything that you need to know about combat in the game. That isn't to imply that there aren't specialty moves like countering, but for 95% of the encounters in the game, you can get through them with a minimal amount of effort.

The game's environments looks nice, but most levels feel too long, like the developers were trying to increase the game's length without factoring in what they would do to it quality.  This is a common problem that a lot of games have, since pacing is hard to do.  What makes this noticeable worst is the lack of challenge on most levels. With a simple combat system, and a very simple platforming system (you push jump to pretty much do everything, and there only one correct path, so can just mindlessly push jump towards the next platform most of the time) eventually enemies and puzzles become annoyances that just slow you down.

In the end, if it was only the main game, I wouldn't recommend this title to others. But what pushes it up, is one of the original DLC pieces, Pigsy's Perfect 10, which comes standard in the steam version, so I am factoring it into the review (since it is now part of the base experience).  This DLC is several hours long and focuses on the side character Pigsy. It has different gameplay (3rd person shooter), an unique story (takes place during the main game events, but before the main cast meets Pigsy), and a different overall theme from the main game (Friendship, loneness, and lost). And while the last level in it goes on for way too long, I would argue that overall it is better than the main game, and makes the ending to the main game more significant and meaningful.

Enslaved: Odyssey to the West is a nice game that does some things right and some things wrong. I wouldn't say it a must play title, but if you can pick it up on sale for cheap, then you should. The overall experience from the main game and the DLC is fun, and who doesn't like having fun.

reviewText: I love this game!  Or perhaps the story and visuals more than anything else.  The camera sucks, and fighting can get repetative but the story, the growing relationship between Monkey and Trip, the artwork...Its adictive.  I havent felt so compelled to finish a game in a long time.  I even like Monkeys acrobatics a lot.  Its pretty fun(although fairly easy) to find a way to jump, swing, and climb around all the obstacles in your path.  The game is also linear but, like I said, the story and its very fleshed out, realistic characters more than make up for any drawbacks.  There are a couple of bugs in the game but none that I didnt easily figure out how to deal with on my own.  For example, the wrecker mek in the fish tank area hit a wall and just kept running against the wall and you cannot progress until you beat him.  Easity fixed by taunting said mek before he ran for the wall.  A lot of it has to do with timing.  Anyway, I overwhelmingly recomend this game.  I never even knew that it existed before it went on sale.  Im so happy that I have it now.

reviewText: Very solid story, especially for the 75% off price. I thoroughly enjoyed it. Has a very likable hero, voiced by the sensational Andy Serkis. The main girl in the game is Trip, voiced by Lindsey Shaw, who is a very despicable character, but only because she's scared. In the end she does realize her flaws, and I guess Monkey forgives her because he finds he fricken attractive as hell. It's not a very long game, which is good for me since I don't have a buttload of time to keep track of a 20+ hour story in a game. The game was well made considering Ninja Theory's team on it. Some scenes feel a little empty, but all of the gameplay is lush and full of beauty. The puzzles are not overly complicated. The flaw that bugs me the most is that game holds your hand almost the whole way through, which can get a little annoying if you just want to get moving, it makes you feel a little helpless just standing there, but better than not knowing where to go/what to do. This game has the best edge grapple/jump gameplay I've ever seen. The main issues with games like Prince of Persia and Assassin's Creed is that the player would randomly jump off a ledge I didn't want them to, or storm into a random direction. Enslaved is so finely programmed that I have not run into a situation where the controls were either unresponsive, or the hero went where I didn't want him to go, or jump higher/lower than I wanted him to. The combat is very fine. Unlocking abilities simply takes resources and not levels or anything. You pick up orbs to gain resources. I thought they'd feel out of place, but in game you're more focused on finding them than realizing if they ruin the scene or not.\nFor those seeking adventure and a hint of romance in a post apocalyptic paradise, look no further.\n8/10

reviewText:
This game REALLY reminded me of the Jak franchise on Playstation 2. The characters were so similar in concept and the ruins and enemies gave me childhood memories. The mechs reminded me of the gladiators that you fight in the arena when you first go into the desert region of Jak 3, the slavers were just like the government in Jak 2, hell even the protagonist, Monkey, looks like Jak.

As mentioned before, the game just gives me constant childhood memories. Collecting orbs that upgrade you, beautiful environments that leave memories in your head forever, quirky voiceacting, and such similar platformer-styled parkour jumping and fighting.

I've only gotten through around 3-4 chapters out of a possible 14 and it's taken me under 2 hours of gameplay. Although there a few graphical errors (odd shading, characters hovering a 10 millimetres from the ground), the game looks beautiful on the Unreal Engine. It's never too hard or too easy, and you're not spoonfed by the developers. It's rather linear and has lack of exploration in certain portions, but you tend to forget about it once you get into the game.

Also, Andy Serkis, voice of Smeagol and the Witch-King from LOTR, is the voice of the protagonist, how ♥♥♥♥ing cool is that?

reviewText: This is for all you 3D nvidia vision users out there. This is a game that came out on the consoles some years ago, I actually have a PS3 copy. All i can say is this was underated when it was released on the consoles, and quite frankly a sleaper hit on the PC. you will need to apply the helix mod, which really makes the 3D world come to life. I will add most of the combat is fairly straightforward, not as deep as some other AAA action titles out there, but it really makes up for it in narrative and sheer beauty of the world. The boss segments are also well done. If there were more 3d titles like this out there, it would be a sheer joy in gamers paradise. Definately worth the play through again even if you have the PS3 version to behold this world in 3d is truely beathtaking.

reviewText:
I was pleasantly surprised to see Namco taking a chance on a script and game like Enslaved Odyssey to the West. The dialogue and interactions between Monkey and Trip as their friendship/enslavedment progresses is entertaining and well written with not a lot of cheesy cringeworthy ENGRISH dialogue or moments.

There's a decent amount of variety in combat, enemies, level design and puzzles to keep you entertained for a while throughout the action packed story. Voice acting is top notch as are Monkey's movement and animations, however most of this kinda goes downhill and stale towards the last 2 hours of the game and the lackluster ending.

The game will sometimes confuse you with its fixed camera angles during certain moments while you climb in order to force a certain perspective or view of the scenery which is quite nice, however this can be a little jarring for the player when they're trying to execute certain jumps in a certain direction. Luckily the climbing and movement for the most part is relatively easy and smooth, with little option to drop to your death.

Firing and combat mechanics do get a little repetitive after a while throughout the game, but every once in a while a puzzle or action sequence is introduced to keep things interesting.

As I said, the final 2 hours of the game and the ending are somewhat lackluster, predictable and practically open ended considering the ride you just went through.

But all things considered, 7.5/10.

The game will sometimes confuse you with its fixed camera angles during certain moments while you climb in order to force a certain perspective or view of the scenery which is quite nice, however this can be a little jarring for the player when they're trying to execute certain jumps in a certain direction. Luckily the climbing and movement for the most part is relatively easy and smooth, with little option to drop to your death.

Firing and combat mechanics do get a little repetitive after a while throughout the game, but every once in a while a puzzle or action sequence is introduced to keep things interesting.

As I said, the final 2 hours of the game and the ending are somewhat lackluster, predictable and practically open ended considering the ride you just went through.

But all things considered, 7.5/10.

reviewText:
This game is a pretty interesting take on the old Chinese tale: Journey to the West. It takes quite a few liberties with the story but the adaptations and changes aren't bad in my opinion.

Pros:
-Great voice acting
-Good Story Telling
-Incredibly colorful and pretty environments

Cons
-Combat is boring as heck
-Story really drags on after a while
-Platforming is really basic

This game's strength lies in its story telling ability....not its gameplay. It's competent in a lot of its core gameplays but I wouldn't describe the actual playing of the game as very fun. What IS entertaining is watching the characters interact and seeing the story progress. It eventually became a matter of springting through most of the level in order to see the next cutscene.

Overall: 6/10 Not a waste of money, but definitely better to wait till it's on sale.

reviewText: A pain to get running optimally. A lot of guides available for it. Other than that, it's a standard 3rd person brawler with an above-average story. I got it on sale for very cheap and recommend that a purchase comes under $10. Once you get past those qualms, this game can be a next-gen looking game with the right hardware, and it has a ton of fun levels. The fighting has a good amount of depth to keep it from getting boring and the enemy types and platforming sections keep it varied. The pacing is all there and the characters are well-written. I had no idea that Andy Serkis (guy that did like every CGI character since Gollum) played the main character until the end, and that makes a lot of sense.

Enslaved PC review text version:



Ninja Theory have had some time to tweak and fix Enslaved on PC, but sadly and evidently have not, leaving the vanilla game a bit of a shambles which is a shame. If you have a controller and mess with the game files, then there is a decent game here that’s worth playing, especially for the asking price (if these issues were fixed, then add a few points on to the final score). As it stands,  Enslaved doesn't possess the kind of polish or user interface expected from today’s games and therefore scores less than its console cousin. The cool gameplay moments and neat storytelling on offer are simply overshadowed by the negatives, and if you are stuck with the headache inducing motion blur , it's likely you'll switch the game off way before the story gathers any pace.

Score 4.5/10 - Review by Robert Cram

reviewText: This game has some wired camera issues, but besides this it is a charm. The game often takes control of the camera and you are not able to look around freely. Her beauty in shape and character is amazing ... just a dream. I bought it 3 days ago, play it in hard mode using a mouse and keyboard and enjoy it. The fights are tough, the environment colorful and lively and the story is very lovely. If you enjoy puzzles, finding hidden stuff, challenging fights and a well told story then you should consider buying this game. For me it's a small gem already.

reviewText:
Bought it in the summer sale for 5€ - and it really was a good idea.
It takes about 2 h to really get into the story, so don't give up too early.
It's basically Tomb raider with three nicely written characters.
Although there is much jumping and climbing involved it never get's unfair (in fact it is quite easy).

Pros:
+ Slightly above average graphics and animations
+ Scenery changes often enough
+ Music, sound and voice cast are quite good
+ Story is OK
+ Easy to learn and master the action oriented battle system
+ mouse and keyboard worked well for me (I hate controllers)
+ well implemented automatic saving system
+ Even sometimes some thinking is required
+ Never got lost in even the bigger levels
+ Game is not prolonged artificially (ca. 10h without rushing)
+ Frequent phases with no fighting

Cons:
- Camerasystem (occasionally switching between free and fixed) sometimes disturbing
- only 5 enemy types
- Battles become monotonous after a while (quite easy on normal difficulty)

Final verdict:
One of the better console ports - definately worth the 5€.
